chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the contraindications and cautions for oral fluconazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Avoid oral fluconazole in:
    • People with acute porphyria.
    • Pregnant women.
    • People taking other drugs known to prolong the QT interval and which are metabolized via the cytochrome P450 (such as erythromycin).
  • Use oral fluconazole with caution in:
    • People at risk of QT prolongation — this includes people with cardiomyopathy, sinus bradycardia, arrhythmias, hypokalaemia, hypomagnesaemia, hypocalcaemia, or who are taking other medication known to cause QT prolongation (such as tricyclic antidepressants, antipsychotics, or antiarrhythmics).
    • Hepatic impairment or people taking concurrent hepatotoxic drugs — associated with serious hepatic toxicity including fatalities.
    • Renal impairment if estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is less than 50 ml per minute per 1.73m2 — use the usual initial dose then halve the subsequent doses.

[ABPI 2018; BNF, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of oral fluconazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Adverse effects reported commonly include:
    • Headache, skin reactions, nausea, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and flatulence.
    • Rare cases of agranulocytosis, neutropenia, QT prolongation, and serious hepatotoxicity have been reported.

[ABPI 2018; BNF, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the drug interactions of oral fluconazole?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Fluconazole inhibits cytochrome P450 enzymes (CYP450), and may, therefore, increase the levels of many drugs that are metabolised by the CYP450.
  • Drug interactions include:
    • Amiodarone — concomitant use may increase QT prolongation.
    • Antidiabetic drugs — frequent monitoring of blood glucose is recommended owing to reports of hypoglycaemia following concurrent use.
    • Antiretroviral drugs — fluconazole increases the levels of nevirapine, ritonavir, and tipranavir. Monitor for signs of increased adverse effects. Avoid doses of fluconazole greater than 200 mg daily.
    • Carbamazepine and phenytoin — plasma levels of these drugs are increased by fluconazole, and toxicity has been reported. Monitoring and dose adjustment are indicated.
    • Celecoxib — fluconazole increases plasma concentrations of celecoxib, manufacturer advises adjusting celecoxib dose.
    • Erythromycin — concomitant use is contraindicated as this may increase the risk of cardiotoxicity (prolonged QT interval, Torsades de Pointes).
    • Ergotamine and methysergide — avoid concurrent use, owing to the increased risk of ergotism.
    • Ciclosporin — fluconazole increases the concentration of ciclosporin, manufacturer advises caution.
    • Statins — fluconazole potentially increases the risk of rhabdomyolysis when given with atorvastatin, monitoring and adjustment of dose are recommended.
    • Theophylline — predicted to cause hypokalaemia (potentially increasing the risk of Torsade de Pointes) when given with fluconazole.
    • Tacrolimus — fluconazole is predicted to increase tacrolimus concentration – monitoring advised.
    • Warfarin — fluconazole inhibits warfarin metabolism by cytochrome P450 CYP2C9. Monitor the international normalized ratio (INR) closely and adjust dose.

[Baxter, 2013; ABPI 2018; BNF, 2020]
